facts.text: In 1961 the appellants, Oriental Mercantile Agency, retrenched six of their workmen resulting in an industrial dispute which was referred by the Government of Madras to the Labour Court for adjudication. The question referred was whether the retrenchment was justified and what relief the workmen were entitled to.
By its award dated June 14, 1963 the Labour Court (Shri S. Abdul Azeez) held that the retrenchment of the workmen was justified and therefore they were not entitled to any relief.
Against the award of the Labour Court the workmen filed writ petition No. 209 of 1964 in the Madras High Court, under Article 226 of the Constitution.

Venkatadri J. by his judgment dated February 20, 1967 set aside the award, held that the retrenchment was unjustified, the intention of the management was to weed out those whom it did not want and that the reasons given by the management were fanciful, and remitted the matter back to the Labour Court for fresh disposal.

The appellants filed writ appeal No. 113 of 1967 against the judgment of Venkatadri J. That appeal came for hearing before Anantanarayanan C.J. and Natesan J., who by their order dated April 4, 1967 dismissed the appeal in limine without issuing notice to the workmen, observing that Venkatadri J. had not expressed final conclusions on major questions of fact and that the Labour Court should ascertain facts afresh.

While the matter was pending before the Labour Court, the workmen moved CMP No. 7125 of 1967 seeking clarification of Venkatadri J.'s judgment dated February 20, 1967. By order dated June 26, 1967 Venkatadri J. clarified that he had remitted only for determining reliefs, that retrenchment was unjustified finding was final, and Labour Court could not reopen merits.

The management filed CMP No. 8579 of 1967 for review of the order dated April 4, 1967 in Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967. The Division Bench (Anantanarayanan C.J. and Natesan J.) dismissed it by order dated July 31, 1967.

By its award dated May 25, 1968 the Labour Court (Shri S. Gonsalves) held retrenchment justified, relying on the writ appeal dismissal observations that High Court observations on remission are obiter and matter at large.

Against that award the workmen filed Writ Petition No. 122 of 1969, referred to Division Bench. By judgment dated July 7, 1970 Veeraswami C.J. and Gokulkrishnan J. quashed the award and directed Labour Court not to go into merits but only reliefs, holding Venkatadri J.'s order final and binding.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court: Civil Appeal No. 113 of 1971.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Labour Court was bound by the finding of Venkatadri J. that retrenchment was unjustified, or could re-adjudicate merits in light of subsequent appellate observations and clarifications, amidst conflicting High Court orders.
Legality of the Division Bench order dismissing Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967 in limine without hearing workmen, and effect of clarificatory orders.

petitioner_arguments.text: Management contended before Labour Court that they were entitled to re-agitate the matters in controversy relying on writ appeal observations.

respondent_arguments.text: Workmen objected, contending that Venkatadri J. had recorded specific finding that retrenchment unjustified, binding on Labour Court.

court_reasoning.text: Division Bench in Writ Appeal 113/1967 erred in making observations prejudicing workmen without hearing them; dismissal in limine gave management substantive relief, violating natural justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: True, appeal dismissed but in substance management got relief wanted.

court_reasoning.text: Division Bench erred in viewing Venkatadri J. as not expressing final conclusion; he had, but remitted unfortunately for fresh disposal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Venkatadri J. was right that he decided dispute finally but complicated by remitting for fresh disposal.

court_reasoning.text: Venkatadri J. erred in issuing clarificatory order post-appellate construction, lacking jurisdiction; appellate judgment binding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Learned single Judge seeking without warrant to exercise jurisdiction no longer his.

court_reasoning.text: Labour Court award of 1968 could not stand without High Court testing validity of Venkatadri J.'s judgment in appeal; real controversy missed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court has not tested in appeal the validity of Venkatadri J.'s judgment.

holdings.text: Set aside order dated April 4, 1967 in Writ Appeal No. 113/1967 as violating natural justice.
Set aside clarificatory order dated June 26, 1967 by Venkatadri J. as lacking jurisdiction post-appellate order.
Set aside Labour Court award May 25, 1968 and High Court judgment July 7, 1970.
Revive Writ Appeal No. 113/1967 and direct High Court to dispose on merits after notice to workmen, to test validity of Venkatadri J.'s judgment.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petitions filed under Article 226; High Court powers limited to remitting cases.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside multiple conflicting High Court and Labour Court orders, revived Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967, and directed the Madras High Court to hear and dispose of it on merits after issuing notice to the workmen, to determine the legality of Venkatadri J.'s judgment.
outcome.relief_granted: Revival of Writ Appeal No. 113 of 1967 for hearing on merits

key_quotes.text: "the petition discloses an unfortunate state of affairs."
key_quotes.speaker: high_court
key_quotes.significance: Chief Justice's observation on conflicting orders agreed by Supreme Court.

key_quotes.text: "I am therefore of the opinion that the conclusion of the Labour Court cannot be sustained, on the facts and circumstances of this case."
key_quotes.speaker: venkatadri_j
key_quotes.significance: Venkatadri J. setting aside original Labour Court award.

key_quotes.text: "We have no doubt that the learned Judges who dismissed Writ Appeal 113 of 1967 were, with respect, in error in making observations which were calculated to prejudice the workmen without giving them an opportunity of being heard."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Supreme Court's criticism of Division Bench order.
